instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_L: What is P3V3S5_EN_L? P3V3S5_EN_L is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is low. .
definitions.P5VS3_EN_L: What is P5VS3_EN_L? P5VS3_EN_L is a signal that enables the PP5V_S3 power rail when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
I have an 2879 with no power
initially came in a month ago for no green light no fan spin, fixed no green light by replacing <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR>
was checking rails found 3.3v s3 missing, traced back to <RESISTOR>R7812</RESISTOR>, missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
rabbit hole or not?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: These do not auto power on, short power pads. Also what is resistance to GND on 3V42 rail?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
0.273@<CAPACITOR>C6999</CAPACITOR>, partial short?
shorted <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground and nothing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: [COLOR=#FF0000]RESISTANCE[/COLOR] to GND on 3V42 rail, not diode mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 36k at <CAPACITOR>C6999</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: That could be ok. <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 3.3V dead on pin 1 <RESISTOR>R1987</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: PPBUS even present? <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> area?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: ppbus 12.61@<CAPACITOR>C7331</CAPACITOR> , <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> area was replaced, if i remember correctly the whole place looked messed up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: There is your issue. <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> makes <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> <RESISTOR>R7273</RESISTOR> pin1 3.406v, pin 2 0v, after replacing i get both sides 1.4 Vto 4V, could <CHIP>U7840</CHIP> be bad?   pin 4 <CHIP>U7840</CHIP> is 0.398volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7273</RESISTOR> is for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, not <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. What do you get for <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 0.365V at pin 5 <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>                 2.990V at pin 2 <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"after replacing i get both sides 1.4 Vto 4V"

Well that is messed up. This means <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> is now pulsing? Pretty sure something around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> or <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is messed up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> no change, 1.6v on charger output, no shorts on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3V
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is 0.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0.185v
removed <CHIP>U7840</CHIP> and got 3.4v on pin 1, 1.28V on pin 2, 0.21V on pin 3, 3.3v on pin 6, 0.8v on pin 7, 0v on pin 8

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> is the problem. If it is not pulsing I suspect SMC problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
ok ive tested and, <RESISTOR>R7273</RESISTOR> i get 0V, at pin2 <CHIP>U7840</CHIP> i get 0V
so smc replacement? from what ive heard I have to pull another smc off the exact same model, is that right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: that is right about the smc,  needs to be the exact same model.  first try to reflow the smc just in case a ball is corroded or not connected sometimes this works and saves time and a smc.  if that does not work remove the replacement and old smc very well so that you can just seat the replacement without reballing it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: ok reflow and no change, I dont have the exact board to replace it with so this will have to go on hold unless there are any other ideas

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: please mark this as closed as the owner has cancelled the job, thanks for the assistance
